page.title: List of names for the biblical nameless

revision.text:
{{use dmy dates|date=September 2012}} [[File:MosesRescued FromTheNile.JPG|thumb|right|300px|[[Nicolas Poussin]]'s ''[[Moses]] rescued from the [[Nile]]'' (1638) shows Pharaoh's daughter, who is unnamed in the Bible, but called [[Bithiah]] in Jewish tradition.]] This list provides names given in history and [[tradition]]s for people who appear to be unnamed in the [[Bible]]. ==Old Testament== ===Wives of the antediluvian patriarchs=== {| border="1" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="1" style="width:270px; font-family:Arial Unicode MS, Lucida Sans Unicode; float:right; margin:10px;" |- !Patriarch !Wife |- ||[[Cain]] || [[Awan (religious figure)|Âwân]]
Nod[http://www.avbtab.org/rc/read/nod.htm Nod's Land] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130226033055/http://www.avbtab.org/rc/read/nod.htm |date=26 February 2013 }}. Avbtab.org. |- ||[[Seth]] || Azûrâ |- ||[[Enos (biblical figure)|Enos]] || Nôâm |- ||[[Kenan]] || Mûalêlêth |- ||[[Mahalalel]] || Dinah |- ||[[Jared]] || Baraka |- ||[[Enoch (ancestor of Noah)|Enoch]] || Edna |- ||[[Methuselah]] || Edna |- ||[[Lamech (father of Noah)|Lamech]] (Seth's line) || Betenos |- ||[[Noah]] || Emzârâ
[[Naamah (Genesis)|Naamah]] |} {{see also|Antediluvian}} :Source: the [[Book of Jubilees]] (part of the [[Oriental Orthodox]] [[deuterocanon]]) :Appears in the Bible at: [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] 4–5 The [[Book of Jubilees]] provides names for a host of otherwise unnamed biblical characters, including wives for most of the [[antediluvian]] [[Patriarchs (Bible)|patriarchs]]. The last of these is [[Noah]]'s wife, to whom it gives the name of ''Emzara''. Other Jewish traditional sources contain many different names for Noah's wife. The Book of Jubilees says that Awan was [[Adam and Eve]]'s first daughter. Their second daughter Azura married [[Seth]]. For many of the early wives in the series, ''Jubilees'' notes that the patriarchs married their sisters. The ''[[Cave of Treasures]]'' and the earlier ''Kitab al-Magall'' (part of [[Clementine literature]]) name entirely different women as the wives of the patriarchs, with considerable variations among the extant copies. The Muslim historian [[Ibn Ishaq]] (c. 750), as cited in [[al-Tabari]] (c. 915), provides names for these wives which are generally similar to those in ''Jubilees'', but he makes them [[Cainites]] rather than [[Sethianism|Sethites]], despite clearly stating elsewhere that none of Noah's ancestors were descended from Cain. ===Cain and Abel's sisters=== {{see also|Cain and Abel}} :Name: ''[[Aclima|Calmana]]'' (or Aclima or Luluwa) :source: [[Golden Legend]],[http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/basis/goldenlegend/GoldenLegend-Volume1.htm#Adam Medieval Sourcebook: The Golden Legend: Volume 1 (full text)], Fordham.edu. which also tells stories about many of the saints :Appears in the Bible at: Genesis 4:17 :Name: ''Delbora'' :source: [[Golden Legend]], which also tells stories about many of the saints :Appears in the Bible at: Genesis 4 See also: [[Balbira and Kalmana]], [[Azura (religious figure)|Azura]] and [[Awan (religious figure)|Awan]] for alternate traditions of names. === Noah's wife === {{see also|Noah}} :Name: ''[[Naamah (Genesis)|Naamah]]'' :Source: [[Genesis Rabbah|Midrash Genesis Rabbah]] 23:4 :Appears in the Bible at: Genesis 4:22; Gen. 7:7 Daughter of [[Lamech (descendant of Cain)|Lamech]] and Zillah and sister of [[Tubal-cain]] (Gen. iv. 22). According to Abba ben Kahana, Naamah was Noah's wife and was called "Naamah" (pleasant) because her conduct was pleasing to God. But the majority of the rabbis reject this statement, declaring that Naamah was an idolatrous woman who sang "pleasant" songs to idols. See also [[Wives aboard the Ark]] for a list of traditional names given to the wives of Noah and his sons Shem, Ham, and Japheth. ===Ham's wife=== {{See also|Wives aboard Noah's Ark}} :Name: ''[[Egyptus]]'' :Source: [[Book of Abraham]]   The [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|Mormon]] Book of Abraham, first published in 1842, mentions Egyptus ([http://scriptures.lds.org/en/abr/1/23#23 Abraham 1:23]) as being the name of Ham's wife; his daughter apparently had the same name (v. 25). === Nimrod's wife === {{see also|Nimrod}} :Name: ''[[Semiramis]]'' :Source: ''[[The Two Babylons]]'' by [[Alexander Hislop]]   A large body of legend has attached itself to Nimrod, whose brief mention in ''Genesis'' merely makes him "a mighty hunter in the face of the [[Tetragrammaton|Lord]]". (The Biblical account makes no mention of a wife at all.) These legends usually make Nimrod to be a sinister figure, and they reach their peak in Hislop's ''The Two Babylons'', which make Nimrod and Semiramis to be the original authors of every false and [[paganism|pagan]] religion. ===Mother of Abraham=== :Name: ''Amthlai bath (daughter of) Khrubu'' :Source: [[Babylonian Talmud]] Tractate Baba Bathra Chapter 5[http://sacred-texts.com/jud/t07/t0709.htm The Babylonian Talmud, Rodkinson tr., Book 7.: Tract Baba Bathra, Part I: Chapter V]. [[Sacred-texts.com]]. :Appears in the Bible at: [[Book of Genesis]] ===Lot's married daughter=== {{see also|Lot's daughters}} Name: ''Paltith'' :Source: [[Sefer haYashar (midrash)|Book of Jasher]] 19:24[http://sacred-texts.com/chr/apo/jasher/19.htm Book of Jasher, Chapter 19]. Sacred-texts.com. :Appears in the Bible at: [[Book of Genesis]] ===Lot's wife=== :Name: ''Ado'' ( or ''Edith'' ) :Source: [[Sefer haYashar (midrash)|Book of Jasher]] 19:52
:Appears in the Bible at: [[Book of Genesis]] ===Laban's wife=== :''Adinah redirects here. For other uses, see [[Adinah (disambiguation)]]'' :Name: ''Adinah'' :Source: [[Sefer haYashar (midrash)|Book of Jasher]] 28:28
[http://sacred-texts.com/chr/apo/jasher/28.htm Book of Jasher, Chapter 28]. [https://www.ucalgary.ca/~elsegal/Shokel/960102_Joseph.html] Also, the Persian mystical poem "[[Yusuf and Zulaikha]]" by [[Jami]]. :Appears in the Bible at: Genesis 39:12 Potiphar's wife attempted to seduce [[Joseph (Hebrew Bible)|Joseph]] in Egypt. === Pharaoh's daughter === :Name: Merris :Source: Eusebius of Caesarea (Preparation for the Gospel 9.15) :Name: Merrhoe :Source: Eustathius of Antioch (Commentary on Hexameron MPG 18.785) :Name: ''[[Thermutis]]'' :Source: Flavius Josephus :Name: ''[[Bithiah]]'' or ''Bitya'' :Source: Jewish tradition :Appears in the Bible at: [[Book of Exodus|Exodus]] 2 :Name: ''[[Sobekneferu]]'' or ''Neferusobek'' :Source: ''Unwrapping the Pharaohs'' :{{cite book |last1=Ashton |first1=John |last2=Down |first2=David |date=22 September 2006 |title=Unwrapping the Pharaohs |url=https://answersingenesis.org/answers/books/unwrapping-pharaohs/ |location= |publisher=Master Books |pages=87–90 |chapter=Chapter 12: Pharaohs of the Oppression |chapterurl=https://answersingenesis.org/archaeology/ancient-egypt/pharaohs-of-the-oppression/ |isbn=978-0-890-51468-9 |access-date=3 February 2015}} Pharaoh's daughter, who drew [[Moses]] out of the water, is known as ''[[Bithiah]]'' in Jewish tradition (identifying her with the "Pharaoh's daughter Bithiah" in [[Books of Chronicles|1 Chronicles]] 4:18). ===Simeon's wife=== :Name: Bunah :Source: [[Sefer haYashar (midrash)|Book of Jasher]] 34:36[http://www.sacred-texts.com/chr/apo/jasher/34.htm Book of Jasher, Chapter 34]. [[Chronicles of Jerahmeel]], [[Chester Beatty Papyri|Papyrus Chester Beatty XVI]]: ''The Apocryphon of Jannes and Jambres'' :Appears in the Bible at: [[Book of Exodus|Exodus]] 7 The names of Jannes and Jambres, or Jannes and Mambres, were well known through the ancient world as magicians. In this instance, nameless characters from the [[Hebrew Bible]] are given names in the [[New Testament]]. Their names also appear in numerous Jewish texts. === The Cushitic wife of Moses === :Name: [[Tharbis]] :Source: Flavius Josephus, Jewish Antiquities, Book II, Chapter 10 :Appears in the Bible at: [[Book of Numbers|Numbers]] 12 :Name: ''Adoniah'' :Source: Book of Jasher, 23.5–25.5 [[File:Georges de La Tour 044.jpg|thumb|right|180px|[[Georges de La Tour]],
''Job Mocked by his Wife''.]] === Job's wives === :Names: ''Sitis'', ''Dinah'' :Source: The apocryphal [[Testament of Job]][http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=332&letter=J Job, Testament Of:]. JewishEncyclopedia.com. :Appears in the Bible at: [[Book of Job]] Apocryphal Jewish folklore says that Sitis, or Sitidos, was Job's first wife, who died during his trials. After his temptation was over, the same sources say that [[Job (biblical figure)|Job]] remarried [[Dinah]], [[Jacob]]'s daughter who appears in Genesis. :Name: ''Raḥma'' :Source: Islamic traditionEric Geoffroy et Néfissa Geoffroy : Le grand livre des prénoms arabes – Plus de 5500 prénoms classés par thèmes avec leurs correspondances en français, Albin Michel, 2009. The source does not tell which wife of Job has this name. === Jephthah's daughter === {{see also|Jephthah's daughter}} :Name: ''Seila'' :Source: ''[[Pseudo-Philo|Liber Antiquitatum Biblicarum]]'' :Name: ''Adah'' :Source: [[Order of the Eastern Star]][http://www.scoes.org/adah.htm Adah] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129031511/http://scoes.org/adah.htm |date=29 November 2010 }}, South Carolina Order of the Eastern Star website. :Appears in the Bible at: [[Book of Judges|Judges]] 11 The ''[[Pseudo-Philo|Liber Antiquitatum Biblicarum]]'' falsely ascribes itself to the Jewish author [[Philo]]. It in fact did not surface until the sixteenth century; see ''[[Works of Philo]]''. ===Samson's mother=== {{see also|Wife of Manoah}} :Name: ''[[Hazelelponi|Z'llpunith]]'' :Source: [[Babylonian Talmud]] Tractate Baba Bathra Chapter 5 :Appears in the Bible at: [[Book of Judges]] 13 ===David's mother=== :Name: [[Nitzevet|Nzb'th, daughter of Edal]] :Source: [[Babylonian Talmud]] Tractate Baba Bathra Chapter 5 (folio 91a) :Appears in the Bible at: [[Book of Samuel]] === The Witch of Endor === [[File:Saul and the Witch of Endor by Jacob Cornelisz van Oostsanen.jpg|right|thumb|250px|''Saul and the Witch of Endor'' by [[Jacob Cornelisz van Oostsanen]], 1526.]] {{see also|Witch of Endor}} :Name: ''Sedecla'' :Source: ''[[Pseudo-Philo|Liber Antiquitatum Biblicarum]]'' :Appears in the Bible at: [[Books of Samuel|1 Samuel]] 28 ===The Man of God=== :Name: ''[[Iddo (prophet)|Iddo]]'' :Source:[http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/8048-iddo Jewish Encyclopedia] :Appears in the Bible at: [[2 Chronicles]] 12:15 and [[1 Kings]] 13 === The wise woman of Abel === {{see also|Wise woman of Abel}} :Name: ''[[Serah]]'' :Source: [[Aggadah|Aggadic Midrash]][[Rashi]] on [http://www.chabad.org/library/bible_cdo/aid/15880/showrashi/true 2 Samuel 20:19]. :Appears in the Bible at: [[Books of Samuel|2 Samuel]] 20 === The Queen of Sheba === [[File:Horse-sheba.jpg|thumb|right|250px|An Ethiopian [[fresco]] of the Queen of Sheba travelling to Solomon.]] {{see also|Queen of Sheba}} :Name: ''Makeda'' :Source: Traditional [[Ethiopia]]n lore surrounding Emperor [[Menelik I]]; see the ''[[Kebra Nagast]]'' :Name: ''Nicaule'' :Source: [[Josephus]] :Name: ''[[Bilqis]]'' :Source: Islamic traditions :Appears in the Bible at: 1 [[Books of Kings|Kings]] 10; 2 [[Books of Chronicles]] 9 According to Ethiopian traditions, the Queen of Sheba returned to Ethiopia pregnant with King [[Solomon]]'s child. She bore Solomon a son that went on to found a [[dynasty]] that ruled Ethiopia until the fall of Emperor [[Haile Selassie]] in 1974. === Jeroboam's wife === {{see also|Wife of Jeroboam}} :Name: Ano :Source: [[Septuagint]] :Appears in the Bible at: 1 [[Books of Kings|Kings]] 14 ===Haman's mother=== :Name: ''Amthlai daughter of Urbthi'' :Source: [[Babylonian Talmud]] Tractate Baba Bathra Chapter 5 :Appears in the Bible at: [[Book of Esther]] ==Old Testament deuterocanonicals== [[File:Ciseri, Antonio - Das Martyrium der sieben Makkabäer - 1863.jpg|thumb|upright|right|[[Antonio Ciseri|Ciseri]]'s ''Martyrdom of the Seven Maccabees'' (1863) depicts the [[woman with seven sons]].]] The [[Deuterocanonical books]], sometimes called the "[[Biblical apocrypha|Apocrypha]]", are considered canonical by Catholics, [[Eastern Orthodox]], and [[Oriental Orthodox]] (though these churches' lists of books differ slightly from each other). === The woman with seven sons === The [[woman with seven sons]] is a Jewish [[martyr]] who is unnamed in [[2 Maccabees]] 7, but is named Hannah, Miriam, Shamuna and Solomonia in other sources. According to Eastern Orthodox tradition, her sons, the "Holy Maccabean Martyrs" (not to be confused with the martyrs in the [[Ethiopian Orthodox Church|Ethiopian]] book of [[Meqabyan]]), are named Abim, Antonius, Gurias, Eleazar, Eusebonus, Alimus and Marcellus. === The seven Archangels === [[Book of Tobit|Tobit]] 12:15 reads "I am Raphael, one of the [[Seven archangels|seven holy angels]], which present the prayers of the saints, and which go in and out before the glory of the Holy One."[http://etext.virginia.edu/etcbin/toccer-new2?id=KjvTobi.sgm&images=images/modeng&data=/texts/english/modeng/parsed&tag=public&part=12&division=div1 Tobit 12:15]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Etext.virginia.edu. Of the six unnamed [[seven Archangels|archangels]], [[Michael (archangel)|Michael]] is named in the [[Book of Daniel]], and [[Gabriel]] is named in the [[Gospel of Luke]].[[Book of Daniel|Daniel]] 12:1; [[Gospel According to Luke|Luke]] 1:19. The [[Book of Enoch]], deuterocanonical in the [[Ethiopian Orthodox Church]], names the remaining four archangels [[Uriel]], [[Raguel (angel)|Raguel]], [[Zerachiel]], and [[Ramiel]].[http://www.sacred-texts.com/bib/boe/boe023.htm Enoch XX]. Sacred-texts.com. Other sources name them Uriel, Izidkiel, [[Haniel]], and Kepharel.James Hastings, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=ynjtxhjj4QkC&pg=PA201 A Dictionary of the Bible: Volume IV, Part I: Pleroma–Shimon]'', 1898, reprinted 2004 by the Minerva Group, {{ISBN|1-4102-1728-0}}, p. 202 (RAPHAEL). In the [[Coptic Orthodox Church]] the names of these four archangels are given as Suriel, Sedakiel, Sarathiel and Ananiel. Several other sets of names have also been given. ==New Testament== === The Magi === [[File:Magi (1).jpg|thumb|300px|The [[Three Wise Men]] are given the names Caspar, Melchior, and Balthasar in this late 6th century [[mosaic]] from the [[Basilica]] of [[Basilica of Sant'Apollinare Nuovo|Saint Apollinarius]] in [[Ravenna]], Italy.]] {{main article|Biblical Magi}} :Names: ''Balthasar, Melqon, Gaspar'' :Source: ''Armenisches Kindheitsevangelium'' Wilhelm Schneemelcher, Neutestamentarische Apokryphen. In deutscher Übersetzung: 2 Bde., Mohr Siebeck; 1999 :Names: ''Balthasar, Melchior, and Caspar (or Gaspar)'' :Source: European folklore :Names: ''Basanater, Hor, and Karsudan'' :Source: The ''[[Book of Adam]]'', an apocryphal [[Ethiopia]]n text :Names: ''Larvandad, Hormisdas, and Gushnasaph'' :Source: [[Syria]]n Christian folklore :Names: ''Manatho, Alchor, and Gaspar'' :Source: White Shrine Of Jerusalem - Masonic :Appear in the Bible at: Matthew 2 The Gospel does not state that there were, in fact, three magi or when exactly they visited Jesus, only that multiple magi brought three gifts: gold, [[frankincense]], and [[myrrh]]. Nevertheless, the number of magi is usually extrapolated from the number of gifts, and the [[three wise men]] are a staple of Christian [[nativity scene]]s. While the European names have enjoyed the most publicity, other faith traditions have different versions. According to the ''Armenisches Kindheitsevangelium'', the three magi were brothers and kings, namely Balthasar, king of India; Melqon, king of [[Persia]]; and Gaspar, king of [[Arabia]]. The [[Christianity in China#Christianity in the contemporary PRC|Chinese Christian Church]]{{clarify|reason=Which one?|date=May 2013}} believes that the [[astronomer]] [[Liu Shang]] was one of the wise men. === The Nativity shepherds === [[File:Kölner Maler um 1330 001.jpg|right|thumb|200px|The Shepherds]] {{main article|Annunciation to the shepherds}} :Names: ''Asher, Zebulun, Justus, Nicodemus, Joseph, Barshabba, and Jose'' :Source: The Syrian ''[[Book of the Bee]]'' :Appear in the Bible at [[Gospel of Luke|Luke]] 2 The ''Book of the Bee'' was written by Bishop Shelemon in the [[Aramaic language]] in the thirteenth century. === Sisters/step-sisters/female cousins of Jesus === :Names: ''Maria'' :Source: ''[[Gospel of Philip]]''Wilhelm Schneemelcher, Neutestamentarische Apokryphen. In deutscher Übersetzung: 2 Bde., Mohr Siebeck; 1999, Vol. 1, p. 159 :Names: ''Lysia and Lydia'' :Source: ''[[History of Joseph the Carpenter]]''Wilhelm Schneemelcher, Neutestamentarische Apokryphen. In deutscher Übersetzung: 2 Bde., Mohr Siebeck; 1999, Vol. 1, p. 363 :Names: ''Maria or Anna, Salomé'' :Source: ''Epiphanus'' The fact that Jesus had at least two sisters/stepsisters/female cousins is mentioned in [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]] 12:50 and [[Gospel of Mark|Mark]] 3:32–34 though their exact number is not specified in either gospel. In addition, the various versions of Epiphanus differ on whether one of the sisters was named Maria or Anna. === The Innocents === {{Main article|Massacre of the Innocents}} :Names: [[Sicarius of Brantôme]], [[St. Memorius]] :Source: [[Helena (empress)|St. Helena]]{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-1HS5gCZ1w4C&pg=PA46|first=Patricia Healy |last=Wasyliw|title=Martyrdom, Murder, and Magic: Child Saints and Their Cults in Medieval Europe|volume=2|publisher=Peter Lang|year=2008|isbn=0-8204-2764-0|page=46}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dA-Fq90TD1QC|first=Thomas J. |last=Craughwell|title=Saints Preserved: An Encyclopedia of Relics|publisher=Doubleday Religious Publishing Group|year=2011|page=267}}Jean Du Puy, ''L'Etat de l'Eglise du Périgord depuis le christianisme'' (Daloy, 1629), Original from Lyon Public Library (Bibliothèque jésuite des Fontaines). Digitized 20 Dec 2010, p. 268.{{cite web|url=http://perigord-dronne-belle.fr/en/abbatiale-saint-pierre-de-brantome-PCUAQU024FS000K2/|title=Abbatiale Saint-Pierre de Brantôme|year=|publisher=PÉRIGORD Dronne Belle|accessdate=9 March 2015}} :Appears in the Bible at: [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]] 2:6–18 The [[Massacre of the Innocents]] was the infanticide of all young male children in the vicinity of Bethlehem ordered by [[Herod the Great]] so as to avoid the loss of his throne to a newborn King of the Jews whose birth had been announced to him by the [[Magi]]. None of the victims are named by Matthew, but a number of supposed victims were identified some centuries later, when their purported relics were found. === Herodias' daughter === :Name: ''[[Salome]]'' :Source: The ''[[Jewish Antiquities]]'' of [[Josephus]],{{cite web|url=http://sacred-texts.com/jud/josephus/ant-18.htm |title=Antiquities of the Jews – Book XVIII |publisher=Sacred-texts.com |accessdate=2010-08-12}} although that reference does not connect her with John the Baptist. :Appears in the Bible at: [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]] 14, [[Gospel of Mark|Mark]] 6 === Syrophoenician woman === {{Main|Exorcism of the Syrophoenician woman's daughter}} :Name: ''Justa'' :Source: 3rd century pseudo-[[Clementine literature|Clementine homily]] Orthodox Church Fathers, Pseudo-Clementine Literature, [http://orthodoxchurchfathers.com/fathers/anf08/anf0846.htm Chapter XIX.- Justa, a Proselyte], accessed 31 December 2017 :Appears in the Bible at: [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]] 15, [[Gospel of Mark|Mark]] 7 According to the same source, her daughter was ''Berenice''. === Hæmorrhaging woman === :Name: ''Berenice'' :Source: The apocryphal ''[[Acts of Pilate]]'' :Name: ''[[Saint Veronica|Veronica]]'' :Source: Latin translation of the ''[[Acts of Pilate]]'' :Appears in the Bible at: {{bibleref|Matthew|9:20–22}} ''Veronica'' is a Latin variant of ''Berenice'' ({{lang-el|Βερενίκη}}). Veronica or Berenice obtained some of Jesus' blood on a cloth at the [[Crucifixion]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2016}} Tradition identifies her with the woman who was healed of a bleeding discharge in the Gospel (see also: [[Veil of Veronica]]). === Samaritan woman at the well === :Name: ''[[Photini]]'' :Source: [[Eastern Orthodox]] Church Tradition :Appears in the Bible at: John 4:5–42 In the tradition of the Eastern Orthodox Church, the name of the woman at the well when she met Jesus is unknown, but she became a follower of Christ, received the name Photini in baptism, proclaimed the Gospel over a wide area, and was later martyred. She is recognized as a saint in the Eastern Orthodox Church. === Damned rich man === :Name: ''[[Nineveh]]'' :Source: [[Coptic language|Coptic]] folklore :Name: ''Phineas'' :Source: Pseudo-[[Cyprian]], ''De pascha computus'' :Name: ''[[Lazarus and Dives|Dives]]'' :Source: European Christian folklore :Appears in the Bible at: {{bibleref|Luke|16:19–31}} ''Dives'' is simply [[Latin]] for "rich", and as such may not count as a proper name. The story of the blessed [[Lazarus and Dives|Lazarus]] and the [[Damnation#Religious|damned]] rich man is widely recognised under the title of ''Dives and Lazarus'', which may have resulted in this word being taken for a proper name. === Woman taken in adultery === :Name: ''[[Mary Magdalene]]'' :Source: Western Christian tradition :Appears in the Bible at: [[Gospel of John|John]] 8 A long-standing Western Christian tradition first attested by [[Pope Gregory I]] identifies the woman taken in [[adultery]] with Mary Magdalene, and also with [[Mary of Bethany]].[http://www.ansa.it/site/notizie/awnplus/english/news/2008-12-10_110304839.html Italians find 'Jesus' foot salve'], 10 Dec 2008 Jesus had [[exorcism|exorcised]] seven [[demons]] out of Mary Magdalene ([[Gospel of Mark|Mark]] {{bibleverse-nb||Mark|16:9|KJV}}), and Mary Magdalene appears prominently in the several accounts of Jesus' entombment and resurrection, but there is no indication in the Bible that clearly states that Mary Magdalene was the same person as the adulteress forgiven by Jesus. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] has never identified Mary Magdalene as either the woman taken in adultery, or the sinful woman who anointed Jesus' feet. === The man born blind === :Name: ''[[Celidonius]]'' :Source: Christian tradition :Appears in the Bible at: [[Gospel of John|John]] {{bibleverse-nb||John|9:1–38}} === Pontius Pilate's wife === {{main article|Pontius Pilate's wife}} :Name: ''Claudia'', ''Procla'', ''[[Procula]]'', ''Perpetua'' or ''Claudia Procles'' :Source: European folklore; Dolorous Passion of our Lord Jesus Christ (as "Claudia Procles")[http://www.jesus-passion.com/THE_PASSION3.htm#CHAPTER%20XXIX Dolorous Passion Of Our Lord Jesus Christ]. Jesus-passion.com. :Appears in the Bible at: {{bibleref|Matthew|27:19}} During the [[trial of Jesus]] the wife of [[Pontius Pilate]] sent a message to him saying, "Have nothing to do with that just man; for I have suffered many things this day in a dream because of him." The proposed names of Procla and Procula may not be names at all, but simply a form of Pilate's official title of [[Procurator (Roman)|Procurator]], indicating that she was the Procurator's wife. === Thieves crucified with Jesus === :Names: ''Titus'' and ''Dumachus'' :Source: ''[[Arabic Infancy Gospel|Arabic Gospel of the Infancy of the Saviour]]'' :Names: ''[[Dismas]]'' and ''[[Gestas]]'' (or, ''Gesmas'') :Source: ''[[Acts of Pilate]]'' :Names: ''Demas'' (the [[penitent thief|good thief]]) :Source: ''[[Narrative of Joseph of Arimathea]]''{{Cite book |title=The Apocryphal Gospels: Texts and Translations |last1=Ehrman |first1=Bart |last2=Plese |first2=Zlatko |authorlink1=Bart D. Ehrman |authorlink2=Zlatko Pleše |year=2011 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |location=New York |isbn=9780199732104 |page=582 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xqQ9LSzs8hgC&printsec=frontcover&dq=a+man+named+demas&hl=en&sa=X&ei=sB0kVJqVBMe9igKi2IE4&output=reader&pg=GBS.PA568 }} :Appear in the Bible at: Matthew 27, Mark 15, Luke 23, John 19 The good thief is revered under the name Saint Dismas in the Catholic Church and the [[Coptic Orthodox Church]]. === Soldier who pierced Jesus with a spear === [[File:Fra Angelico 027.jpg|thumb|Jesus' side is pierced with a spear, [[Fra Angelico]] (''circa'' 1440), Dominican monastery of San Marco, [[Florence]]]] :Name: ''[[Saint Longinus|Longinus]]'' :Source: ''[[Acts of Pilate]]'' :Appears in the Bible at: [[Gospel of John|John]] 19:34 In tradition, he is called ''Cassius'' before his conversion to Christianity.[http://www.heiligenlexikon.de/Stadler/Longinus.html "Longinus"], in: Johann Evangelist Stadler ''et al.'', ''Vollständiges Heiligen-Lexikon'', 1858–1882 (reprint: Hildesheim, 1996) The ''[[Holy Lance|Lance of Longinus]]'', also known as the ''[[Spear of Destiny]]'', is supposedly preserved as a [[relic]], and various miracles are said to be worked through it. === Man who offered Jesus vinegar === :Name: ''[[Agathon]]'' :Source: ''[[Codex Egberti]]'', 10th century :Appears in the Bible at: {{bibleref|Matthew|27:48}}, {{bibleref|Mark|15:36}}, & {{bibleref|John|19:29–30}} === Guard(s) at Jesus' tomb === :Name: ''[[Petronius (centurion)|Petronius]]'' :Source: Apocryphal ''[[Gospel of Peter]]'' :Names: ''Issachar, Gad, Matthias, Barnabas, Simon'' :Source: ''[[The Book of the Bee]]'' :Appears in the Bible at: {{bibleref|Matthew|27:62–66}} === Ethiopian Eunuch baptized by the Apostle Philip === [[File:Rembrandt, The Baptism of the Eunuch, 1626, Museum Catharijneconvent, Utrecht.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Rembrandt]], ''[[The Baptism of the Eunuch]]'', 1626.]] {{main article|Ethiopian eunuch}} :Name: ''Simeon Bachos'' :Source: ''[[Adversus haereses]]'' (''Against the Heresies'', an early anti-[[Gnostic]] theological work) 3:12:8 (180 AD) :Name: ''Bachos'' :Source: [[Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church|Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo]] tradition{{cite book|last=Paulos|first=Abune|title=The Mariological tradition of the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church|year=1988|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|location=New Jersey}} In Eastern Orthodox tradition{{citation/make link|http://www.stmichaeleoc.org/Church_History.htm|History of the Church}} he is known as an Ethiopian Jew with the name Simeon also called the Black, the same name he is given in the Acts of the Apostles 13:1. :Appears in the Bible at: {{bibleref|Acts|13:1}} ===Daughters of Philip=== :Name: ''[[Hermione of Ephesus|Hermione]]''; ''Eutychis''; ''Irais'' and ''Chariline'' :Source: Traditional. See [[Daughters of Philip]] Appears in the Bible:[[Acts of the Apostles]] 21.8-9 ==See also== *[[Brother of Jared]] *[[Seventy Disciples]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== *"Names for the Nameless", in ''The Oxford Companion to the Bible'', [[Bruce M. Metzger]] and [[Michael D. Coogan]], editors. {{ISBN|0-19-504645-5}} *"The [[Poem of the Man God]]", Centro Editoriale Valtortiano srl, [[Maria Valtorta]]. (5 Volumes) no ISBN. {{New Testament people}} [[Category:Bible-related lists of people|*nameless]] [[Category:Christian folklore]] [[Category:Hebrew Bible people| ]] [[Category:Jewish folklore]] [[Category:Lists of names|Biblical nameless]] [[Category:Unidentified people]]

revision.text:
{{redirect|Monkey tree|the tree popularly known as the Monkey-puzzle Tree|Araucaria araucana}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Monkey tree, Jurong West, The New Paper, Sep 07.jpg|thumb|240px|right|The discovery of an outline of [[monkey]]s on a callused tree trunk in [[Jurong West New Town]] has initiated a minor [[social mania]] in [[Singapore]], drawing large crowds to the tree. {{deletable image-caption}}]] --> The '''monkey tree phenomenon''' is a [[social phenomenon]] in [[Singapore]], which began in September 2007. It arose from the discovery of a [[callus]] on a [[tree]] in [[Hong Kah]], which appears [[monkey]]-like. Some believe the image to be of divine origin, while others have attributed the phenomenon to the effects of [[pareidolia]], whereby random stimuli are perceived as meaningful. The callus has initiated a minor [[social mania]], drawing large crowds to look or pray at the tree.
==History==
===Beginnings=== The phenomenon started on 12 September 2007 when an unknown person put up a sign in [[Chinese language|Chinese]] on a tree on Jurong West Street 42. The sign read that a monkey had come to the tree three years ago to look for his father, the Monkey God. It added that a recent [[car accident]] had split the old [[Bark (botany)|bark]] of the tree open, releasing the Monkey God. One resident purported that the monkey image appeared around 3 September 2007.<ref name="Ng Hui Hui">{{cite news| url = http://newpaper.asia1.com.sg/printfriendly/0,4139,141806,00.html| author = Ng Hui Hui| title = Monkey See, Monkey Do?| publisher = ''[[The New Paper]]''| date = 13 September 2007| pages = 12, 13| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071014083330/http://newpaper.asia1.com.sg/printfriendly/0,4139,141806,00.html| archivedate = 14 October 2007| df = }}</ref><ref name="The Straits Times 13 September 2007">{{cite news | author = | title = Monkey Mania | publisher = ''[[The Straits Times]]'' | date = 13 September 2007| page=}}</ref>
The appearance of the sign and the monkey outline on the tree trunk were reported in the local [[English language|English]] and [[Chinese language|Chinese]]-language [[List of newspapers in Singapore|newspaper]]s such as ''[[The New Paper]]'', ''[[The Straits Times]]'' and ''[[Lianhe Zaobao]]''. Reports also quoted residents claiming how three car accidents had earlier happened at the spot, but none had been fatal, purportedly due to the tree's "magical" properties.
Since news broke on 13 September 2007, hundreds of people from all over Singapore have flocked to the usually quiet [[Housing and Development Board|HDB]] neighbourhood to pay [[Homage (arts)|homage]] to the tree. By the afternoon of 13 September, the crowd visiting the tree had swelled to more than 30, with [[Votive offering|offerings]] occupying the grass patch surrounding the tree.<ref name="Ng Hui Hui"/><ref name="mypaper 17 September 2007">{{cite news | author = | title = Public "impatient" to see "Monkey tree" | publisher = ''[[mypaper]]'' | date = 17 September 2007| page=6}}</ref>
===Monkey outline=== The tree with the monkey outline is a species of the [[Khaya|African Mahogany]]. It is a common tree planted by the [[National Parks Board]] (NParks) to provide [[shade (shadow)|shade]], particularly in [[park]]s and along major roads and [[Controlled-access highway|expressways]]. It is a hardy tree that grows well under most soil conditions.
On the trunk of the tree in question is an outline of two monkeys — one larger than the other — with limbs, faces and bodies. They were formed on a surface that is smoother and of a slightly lighter colour than the rest of the trunk. Some people claimed to see three monkeys.
NParks gave a plausible explanation for how the monkey outline could have been formed: The tree was involved in several minor accidents over the years. The uneven bark surface at the base of the tree trunk was the result of callusing, a natural reaction in which the tree grows new bark over injured areas.
The department of [[biological science]]s at the [[National University of Singapore]] explained that patterns formed by callusing are random and depend on the damage caused by the accidents. It added that the monkey outline on the smoother bark may disappear with time as the new [[Tissue (biology)|tissue]] layers form under it and push this layer out. Subsequently, the smooth surface would get darker and rougher, like the rest of the tree bark.
===Public mania=== Devotees to the tree believed that the images are either a manifestation of [[Sun Wukong]], a [[deity]] from [[Chinese mythology]], or [[Hanuman]], the monkey deity in the [[Hindu pantheon]], and that praying to them would bring them luck.<ref name="Zaihan Mohamed Yusof">{{cite news | url=http://newpaper.asia1.com.sg/printfriendly/0,4139,141903,00.html | author = Zaihan Mohamed Yusof| title = So Noisy We Cannot Sleep | publisher = ''[[The New Paper]]'' | date = 14 September 2007| pages=10, 11}}</ref>
The crowd has been leaving bunches of [[banana]]s, packets of [[peanut]]s, [[Orange (fruit)|orange]]s and [[chrysanthemum]] flowers, burning [[joss stick]]s, and praying for lucky [[4-Digits|4-D]] numbers at the tree. People also started burning [[incense]] paper, prompting a resident to place a [[zinc]] barrel beside the tree so that the ashes could be scooped into the barrel.<ref name="Ng Hui Hui"/><ref name="The Straits Times 13 September 2007"/> Some residents even won a bet on the 4-D draw held on 12 September. The winning number "4309" was obtained by combining the HDB block number near the tree (430) and the order of the [[Monkey (zodiac)|Monkey]] in the [[Chinese zodiac]] (ninth).
There were volunteers who helped to distribute the bananas and peanuts to people who drop by. Some of them have also put up signs telling people not to leave [[red packet]]s filled with money beneath the tree. A visitor had left a [[tin can]] containing tiny rolls of paper at the tree.<ref name="Ng Hui Hui"/><ref name="Zaihan Mohamed Yusof"/>
Thousands of people have since visited the ''tree'', and the crowd grew to over 200 at one point on the afternoon of 14 September. The crowd consisted of both men and women, mostly [[Chinese in Singapore|Chinese]] and [[Indians in Singapore|Indians]] of all ages. The people wanted a peek of the monkey images, while many took pictures of the tree with their [[mobile phone]]s. Images of the monkey tree were even sold at [[S$]]3 or S$10 a photograph near the tree.<ref name="Zaihan Mohamed Yusof"/>
The crowds were so large that residents started complaining of the noise, [[littering]] and [[traffic jam]]s caused by vehicles parked illegally along the narrow road. This prompted the [[Singapore Police Force|police]] to patrol the area.<ref name="mypaper 17 September 2007"/><ref name="Zaihan Mohamed Yusof"/>
Two nearby trees also started garnering offerings from 14 September — one for a supposed outline of [[Guan Yin]], the [[Goddess of Mercy]], on its trunk, and another whose bark resembles the [[Hinduism|Hindu]] elephant god [[Ganesha]].<ref name="Zaihan Mohamed Yusof"/><ref name="The Straits Times 15 September 2007">{{cite news | author = | title = Elephantine frenzy at Jurong | publisher = ''[[The Straits Times]]'' | date = 15 September 2007| page=}}</ref>
==Sociological explanations== Many experts interviewed by ''The Straits Times'' thought that the phenomenon could be a case of "believing is seeing".
A [[sociologist]] from the National University of Singapore explained that "those who believe in divine objects are mostly those who follow a simple faith which is founded in tangible evidences of the sacred". He referred to the believers who, in May 2006, flocked to the mountains of [[Mexico]]'s southern [[Chiapas]] state where a rock with an image that resembles [[Jesus Christ]] was discovered.
Another sociologist pointed out that "these objects are called [[Fetishism|fetish]]es or 'objects that are imbued with deep symbolic significance to become sacred objects that embody gods and spirits'." In the monkey tree's case, it was because of a "natural transformation of its material appearance that reminds people of an important legend", and "this form of [[worship]] is actually basic to human religious behaviour".
==See also== *[[Perceptions of religious imagery in natural phenomena]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *{{cite news| url = http://www.dbs.nus.edu.sg/media/info/ST16sep07_.pdf| archive-url = http://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20080421192718/http://www.dbs.nus.edu.sg/media/info/ST16sep07_.pdf| dead-url = yes| archive-date = 21 April 2008| author = Adeline Chia| title = 'Monkey' tree draws crowds: Tree experts say 'monkey' figures are formed by callusing but devotees think otherwise| publisher = ''[[The Sunday Times (Singapore)|The Sunday Times]]''| date = 16 September 2007| page = L4}} archived at {{cite web |url=http://www.dbs.nus.edu.sg/media/ |publisher=National University of Singapore |location=Dpt of Biological Sciences |title=Print Media Highlights |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070613231821/http://www.dbs.nus.edu.sg/media/ |archivedate=2007-06-13 |df= }}
*{{cite news | author = Liu Liyi| title = Jurong West 'Monkey tree' drives new fad (in Mandarin) | publisher = ''[[Lianhe Zaobao]]'' | date = 17 September 2007| page=7}}
==Further reading== *{{cite news | author = Lin Weijie| title = Herd mentality of Singaporeans (in Mandarin) | publisher = ''mypaper'' | date = 24 September 2007| pages=4, 5}}
==External links== *Goh, Charles (16 September 2007). ''[http://api.sg/main/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=96&Itemid=105 Solved - The Case of the Singapore Monkey Tree]''. *[https://www.flickr.com/photos/stay-happy/1460745779/ Image of tree at block 431]<sup>{{Coord|1|21|12.09|N|103|43|17.84|E|display=title,inline}}</sup>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Monkey Tree Phenomenon}} [[Category:Jurong West]] [[Category:Perceptions of religious imagery in natural phenomena]] [[Category:Singaporean culture]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2011}} [[File:Johnlyon1.jpg|right|thumb|[[John Lyon (poet)|John Lyon]], an early Scottish Mormon writer]]
'''Mormon literature''' is generally considered to have begun a few years before the March 1830 publication of the [[Book of Mormon]]. Since then, Mormon literature has grown to include more [[Standard Works|scripture]], as well as [[Latter Day Saint historians|histories]], [[LDS fiction|fiction]], biographies, [[LDS Poetry|poetry]], [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints hymns|hymns]], drama and other forms.
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * ''[[A Believing People]]'' * [[Association for Mormon Letters]] **[[AML Awards]] * [[Bloggernacle]] * [[Richard H. Cracroft]] * [[Eugene England]] * [[Mormon cinema]] * [[Mormon fiction]] * [[Mormon poetry]] * [[List of films of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] * [[List of pageants of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] * [[List of Mormon Cartoonists]] * [[Mormon art]] * [[Mormon folk music]] * [[Mormon music]] * [[A Motley Vision]] * [[Whitney Awards]] {{div col end}}
== References == * [[Eugene England|England, Eugene]]. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20051228120309/http://humanities.byu.edu/mldb/progress.htm Mormon Literature: Progress and Prospects]" in [[David J. Whittaker]], ed., ''Mormon Americana: A Guide to Sources and Collections in the United States''. (Provo, Utah: [[BYU Studies]], 1995)
==External links== * [http://mormonlit.lib.byu.edu/ MLCA database] * [http://mldb.byu.edu/ Mormon literature website] by Gideon Burton at Brigham Young University
[[Category:Latter Day Saint literature| Literature]] [[Category:Latter Day Saint writers| ]]
{{LDS-stub}}

Safa', En Nabi Safa, Mazraet Selsata, Thelthatha |native_name = <!-- for cities whose native name is not in English --> |nickname = |settlement_type = Village |motto = <!-- images and maps |area_total_km2 = <!-- ALL fields dealing with a measurements are subject to automatic unit conversion--> |area_land_km2 = <!--See table @ Template:Infobox Settlement for details on automatic unit conversion--> |area_water_km2 = |area_total_sq_mi = |area_land_sq_mi = |area_water_sq_mi = |area_water_percent = |area_urban_km2 = |area_urban_sq_mi = |area_metro_km2 = |area_metro_sq_mi = |population_density_km2 = |population_density_sq_mi = |population_metro = |population_density_metro_km2 = |population_density_metro_sq_mi = |population_urban = |population_density_urban_km2 = |population_density_urban_sq_mi = |population_blank1_title =Ethnicities |population_blank1 = |population_blank2_title =Religions |population_blank2 = |population_density_blank1_km2 = |population_density_blank1_sq_mi = <!-- General information ---------------> |timezone = |utc_offset = |timezone_DST = |utc_offset_DST = |latd= |longd= |elevation_footnotes = <!--for references: use<ref> </ref> tags--> |elevation_m = |elevation_ft = }}{{Infobox ancient site |name = Nebi Safa |native_name = |alternate_name = Nabi Safa, An Nabi Safa', En Nabi Safa, Thelthatha |image = |alt = |caption = |map_type = Lebanon |map_alt = |map_size = 200 |location = {{convert|13|km|mi}} west of [[Rashaya]] |region = |coordinates = |type = |part_of = |length = |width = |area = |height = |builder = |material = |built = |abandoned = |epochs = |cultures = [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] |dependency_of = |occupants = |event = |excavations = |archaeologists = |condition = Ruins |ownership = |management = |public_access = Yes |website = |notes = }} '''Nebi Safa''', '''Nabi Safa''', '''Neby Sufa''', '''An Nabi Safa''', '''An Nabi Safa'''' or '''En Nabi Safa''' also known as '''Mazraet Selsata''' or '''Thelthatha''' is a [[village]] in the [[Kfar Mishki]] [[municipality]] situated {{convert|13|km|mi}} west of [[Rashaya]] in the [[Rashaya District]] of the [[Beqaa Governorate]] in [[Lebanon]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pleiades.stoa.org/places/678302 |title=Places: 678302 (Nebi Safa) |author1=Brown, J.|author2=Meyers, E. |author3= Talbert, R. |author4= Elliott, T. |author5= Gillies, S. |accessdate=September 19, 2012 |publisher=Pleiades}}</ref><ref name="KrenckerZschietzschmann1938c">{{cite book|author1=Daniel M. Krencker|author2=Willy Zschietzschmann|title=Römische Tempel in Syrien: nach Aufnahmen und Untersuchungen von Mitgliedern der Deutschen Baalbekexpedition 1901–1904, Otto Puchstein, Bruno Schulz, Daniel Krencker|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z68QAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=17 September 2012|year=1938|publisher=W. de Gruyter & Co.}}</ref><ref name="Kaizer2008">{{cite book|author=Ted Kaizer|title=The Variety of Local Religious Life in the Near East in the Hellenistic and Roman Periods|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KgVD3WL0vAsC&pg=PA78|accessdate=19 September 2012|year=2008|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-16735-3|pages=78–}}</ref>
The village is situated in a gap in a ridge overlooking the [[Wadi Al-Taym]] between the [[Merj Shemiseh]] and is predominantly occupied by [[Druze]].<ref name="Curtiss2005">{{cite book|author=Samuel Curtiss|title=Primitive Semitic Religion Today|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qMTRCuk3gD0C&pg=PA83|accessdate=19 September 2012|date=30 January 2005|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|isbn=978-1-4179-7346-0|pages=83–}}</ref> It was visited by [[Edward Robinson (scholar)|Edward Robinson]] in 1852, who noted two [[sarcophagi]] in the area.<ref name="ROBINSON1856">{{cite book|author=E. ROBINSON|title=Biblical Researches in Palestine and the adjacent regions: a journal of Travels in the years 1838 and 1852|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0mst3qxamKAC&pg=PA426|accessdate=19 September 2012|year=1856|publisher=Murray|pages=426–}}</ref>
==Roman temple== There are the ruins of a [[Roman temple]] in the village that is included in a group of [[Temples of Mount Hermon]]. It is larger than the one at [[Hebbariye]], measuring {{convert|72|ft|m}} long (from east to west) and {{convert|35|ft|m}} wide (from north to south). It faces east with a commanding aspect towards [[Mount Hermon]].<ref name="ROBINSON1856"/> It was noted that the view ''"of Hermon from this point is imposing beyond the power of language to express"''.<ref name="Wilson2010">{{cite book|author=Charles Wilson|title=Picturesque Palestiine, Sinai and Egypt|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C1ZIbwAACAAJ|accessdate=19 September 2012|date=3 June 2010|publisher=Sophia Perennis et Universalis|isbn=978-1-59731-459-6}}</ref> George Taylor noted that the doorway of the temple was at least thirty degrees offset from the peak.<ref name="Taylor1971">{{cite book|author=George Taylor|title=The Roman temples of Lebanon: a pictorial guide. Les temples romains au Liban; guide illustré|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ii8NAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=19 September 2012|year=1971|publisher=Dar el-Machreq Publishers}}</ref> The stone blocks used to make the temple were around {{convert|3|ft|m}} thick, not as large as those at Hebbariye and with a lighter [[entablature]] of {{convert|4.5|ft|m}}. It feature an elegant [[pediment]] with graceful architecture. Only the northern wall remains standing with [[pilaster]]s in the northeast corner. The east entrance featured {{convert|3|ft|m}} thick columns that possibly formed a [[portico]].<ref name="ROBINSON1856"/> At the west end of the temple is an [[altar]] with stairs leading down to an underground chamber or crypt that runs for the length of the temple.<ref name="Taylor1971"/> Thirteen courses of stones were recorded by Robinson to a height of {{convert|43.5|ft|m}}.<ref name="ROBINSON1856"/>
The site was suggested to have been used by the [[Druze]] as a [[shrine]] to a [[prophet]] called '''Safa''', who was descended from [[Jacob]] and whose people lived towards [[Hebron]] and [[Jerusalem]]. Little record of the prophet Safa remains, although it was said that "The honourable body is there, and the spirit is always to be found there. Any day that a man seeks him he will find him, it depends on his faith."<ref name="Curtiss2005"/>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.satelliteviews.net/cgi-bin/w.cgi?c=le&UF=-799429&UN=-1157798&DG=CMTY Nebi Safa on sattelliteviews.net] *[http://www.middleeast.com/nebisafa.htm Nebi Safa on middleeast.com] *[http://www.geographic.org/geographic_names/name.php?uni=6521215&fid=3667&c=lebanon Nebi Safa on geographic.org] *[http://www.discoverlebanon.com/en/panoramic_views/roman-temples-lebanon.php Roman Temples on discoverlebanon.com] *[http://www.lebtivity.com/event/hiking-to-kfar-mechki-with-promax Hiking to Kfar Mechki on lebivity.com] *[http://gmap3d.com/?c=le&UF=-799429&UN=6521215&DG=CMTY 3D Google Earth map of En Nebi Safa on www.gmap3d.com] *[http://wikimapia.org/15495759/Nabi-Safa-Mazraet-Selsata Nabi Safa (Mazraet Selsata) on wikimapia] *[http://localiban.org/spip.php?article2563 Nabi Safa on www.localiban.org] *[http://home.us.archive.org/stream/picturesquepales02wilsuoft/picturesquepales02wilsuoft_djvu.txt Full text of Picturesque Palestine, Sinai and Egypt. Edited by Charles Wilson, 1881.] {{Rashaya District}} {{Archaeological sites in Lebanon}} {{Portal|Lebanon|Archaeology|Ancient Near East}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox cave | name = Peik Chin Myaung Cave | photo = Pyin Oo Lwin_60.JPG | photo_caption = [[Stupas]] and [[Stalactites]] inside cave | location = 23km East of [[Pyin Oo Lwin]] | coords={{coord|22|05|45|N|96|37|06|E|display=inline,title}} | depth = {{convert|20|m|ft|abbr=on}} | length = {{convert|1600|m|ft|abbr=on}} <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mrtv3.net.mm/page1/spol.html|title=Sights to See in Pyin Oo Lwin|author=Peik Chin Myaung Cave|accessdate=2012-03-31|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219000525/http://www.mrtv3.net.mm/page1/spol.html|archivedate=2008-12-19|df=}}</ref> | discovery = 1990 by local Nepalese | geology = Limestone | access = Show cave open to the public; water cascade flows from the entrance | survey = | registry = }}
'''Peik Chin Myaung''' is a [[limestone]] [[stalactite]] cave situated south of Wetwun village, near [[Pyin Oo Lwin]], [[Myanmar]]. The cave is an interest site of tourism just 23 km from Pyin Oo Lwin, on the [[Lashio]] road.
==History==
The cave was firstly developed by local Nepalese or [[Gakhars|Gakhar]] and later co-opted by the Myanmar government as a tourist attraction in 1990 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mon-photo.com/Asia/Burma_2/pages/Peik_Chin_Myaung_Cave_1_jpg.htm/|title=Peik Chin Myaung Cave|author=Peik Chin Myaung}}</ref> The cave covers an area of 45 acre, where local plants named Peik Chin, alike long pepper vine used to grow by the mouth of the cave.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ladyphyu.multiply.com/photos/album/239/Peik-chin-myaung_Maha_Nandamu_Cave_at_Pyin-oo-lwinMyanmar?&show_interstitial=1&u=%2Fphotos%2Falbum/| title=Peik Chin Myaung Cave photo album}}</ref><ref>http://www.mrtv3.net.mm/pages/polwin.html</ref> Its history estimated to be 230 millions and 310 millions years old from the formation of limestone and hillocks. After established to enshrine with many Buddhist stupas inside the cave, it also being called Maha Nadamu cave. Despite the imaginable enshrine room to the pilgrimage, the access down to the cave, which leads with a road around 3 km off from Wutwun village, was a tumble countryside road not actually comfortable to access by taxis.
==Local interest==
The local people and many Myanmar pilgrims enjoyed having a good swim at the entrance of the cave. The swallow water flows and cascade from the 600m deep cave. In turns, many locals from Pyin Oo Lwin develop shops with some local products such as wine and dried meat (satt tar chuak) and souvenirs to suit for visitors.<ref>http://www.mmtimes.com/no424/n016.htm/</ref>
==See also==
*[[Pindaya Caves]] *[[Pyin Oo Lwin]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/112.202.166.238|112.202.166.238]] ([[User talk:112.202.166.238|talk]]) to last version by AnomieBOT
revision.text:
{{other uses}} {{Refimprove|date=June 2012}} {{Catholic Church Hierarchy}} '''Prior''', derived from the [[Latin]] for "earlier, first", (or '''prioress''' for nuns) is an [[ecclesiastic]]al [[title]] for a [[Superior (hierarchy)|superior]], usually lower in rank than an [[abbot]] or [[abbess]]. Its earlier generic usage referred to any monastic superior.
==Monastic superiors== In the [[Rule of Saint Benedict]], the term appears several times, referring to any superior, whether an abbot, [[Provost (religion)|provost]], [[Dean (Christianity)|dean]], etc. In other old monastic rules the term is used in the same generic sense.
With the [[Cluniac Reforms]], the term ''prior'' received a specific meaning; it supplanted the provost or dean (''praepositus''), spoken of in the Rule of St. Benedict. The example of the Cluniac congregations was gradually followed by all Benedictine monasteries, as well as by the [[Camaldolese]], [[Vallombrosians]], [[Cistercians]], [[Hirsau Abbey|Hirsau congregations]], and other offshoots of the Benedictine Order.
Monastic congregations of [[hermit]] origin generally do not use the title of abbot for the head of any of their houses, in an effort to avoid the involvement with the world the office of an abbot would entail. As a result, it is not in use for the congregation as a whole. Among them, the equivalent term of '''prior general''' is the one used. This applies, e.g., for the [[Camaldolese]] and the [[Carthusians]].
The term is also used by various [[mendicant order]]s, e.g., the [[Carmelites]] and the [[Dominican Order|Dominicans]]. This applies both to the friars and the nuns of these orders. The term connotes the idea that the '''prior general''' is simply the "first among equals".<ref name="carmfri">Admin (2017-07-05). Carmelite Friars. The British Province of Carmelites, 5 July 2017. Retrieved on 2018-06-08 from http://www.carmelite.org/family/friars.</ref>
===Compound and derived titles=== The [[Benedictine Order]] and its branches, the [[Premonstratensian Order]], and the military orders have three kinds of priors: *the claustral prior *the conventual prior *the obedientiary prior
The '''Claustral prior''' (Latin ''prior claustralis''), called [[dean (religion)|dean]] in a few monasteries, holds the first place after the [[abbot]] (or [[Grand master (order)|grand-master]] in military orders), whom he assists in the government of the monastery, functioning effectively as the abbot's second-in-charge. He has no ordinary jurisdiction by virtue of his office, since he performs the duties of his office entirely according to the will and under the direction of the abbot. His jurisdiction is, therefore, a delegated one and extends just as far as the abbot desires, or the constitutions of the congregation prescribe. He is appointed by the abbot, generally after a consultation in chapter with the professed monks of the monastery, and may be removed by him at any time.
{{anchor|Sub-prior}} <!-- from Sub-prior --> In many monasteries, especially larger ones, the claustral prior is assisted by a '''sub-prior''', who holds the third place in the monastery. In former times there were in larger monasteries, besides the prior and the sub-prior, also a third, fourth and sometimes even a fifth prior. Each of these was called circa (or ''circator''), because it was his duty to make the rounds of the monastery to see whether anything was amiss and whether the brethren were intent on the work allotted to them respectively. He had no authority to correct or punish the brethren, but was to report to the claustral prior whatever he found amiss or contrary to the rules. In the [[Congregation of Cluny]] and others of the tenth, eleventh and twelfth centuries there was also a greater prior (''prior major'') who preceded the claustral prior in dignity and, besides assisting the abbot in the government of the monastery, had some delegated jurisdiction over external dependencies of the abbey. In the high days of Cluny, the abbot was assisted by a [[coadjutor]] styled Grand-Prior (''Grand-prieur'' in French).
The '''Conventual prior''' (Latin ''prior conventualis'') is the independent superior of a monastery that is not an abbey (and which is therefore called a "priory"). In some orders, like the Benedictines, a monastery remains a priory until it is considered stable enough and large enough to be elevated to the rank of an abbey. In other Orders, like the [[Camaldolese]] and [[Carthusians]], conventual priors are the norm and there are no abbots. (The superior of the major houses of Camaldolese nuns, however, is called an [[abbess]].)
This title, in its feminine form '''prioress''', is used for monasteries of nuns in the Dominican and Carmelite orders.
An '''Obedientiary Prior''' heads a monastery created as a satellite of an abbey. When an abbey becomes overlarge, or when there is need of a monastery in a new area, the abbot may appoint a group of monks under a prior to begin a new foundation, which remains a dependency of the mother abbey until such time as it is large and stable enough to become an independent abbey of its own.
A '''Prior Provincial''' is the regional superior of certain Orders, such as the [[Order of Friars Preachers]] [[Dominican Order|Dominicans]] or the [[Carmelite friars]]. In this last case, the head of the whole Order is called the [[prior general]].
Among communities of friars, the second superior is called the [[sub-prior]] and his office is similar to that of the claustral prior in the Benedictine Order.
==Other orders== {{Expand section|date=June 2008}} Some Orders have only one Grand prior (e.g., the [[Portuguese Order of Christ]]).{{fact|date=June 2018}}
Other Orders have several, each in charge of a geographical province called grand priory after him{{clarifyme|date=June 2018}} (as in the [[Order of Malta]]).{{fact|date=June 2018}}
==See also== *[[Catholic religious order]] *[[Priory]]
==References== {{reflist|1}}
==Bibliography== * {{Catholic|wstitle=Prior}} *{{cite EB1911 |last=O'Neill |first=Elizabeth |wstitle=Prior |volume=22|pages=359–360 |short=x}}
==External links==

{{merge|Bhambi Khalpa|discuss=Talk:Rohit (caste)#Proposed merge with Bhambi Khalpa|date=February 2018}} {{Cleanup|reason=Requires editing|date=July 2012}} {{refimprove|date=December 2015}}
'''Rohit''' or '''Rohitas''', also called '''[[Bhambi Khalpa|Bambhi]]''', are a [[chamar]] caste of [[Gujarat]], [[India]].<ref name=R/>
Rohit (or Rohitas) consider themselves to be followers or descendants of the famous saint [[Rohidas]]. Traditionally, they did leather or hide work and were identified as [[Khalpa]]. But in 1947, a group of Khalpa organized and decided to call themselves Rohit. They also abandoned all leather works.<ref name=R/>
The Rohit claim to have sprung from a union between a [[Rajput]] and a low caste woman. In the census of 1961, Rohits have been identified as one of the fifteen sub sections of the [[Chamar]] caste. They claim they are higher than [[Bhangi]]s and also claim to be higher in social hierarchy to [[chamar]]s and [[khalpa]]s. They are a non-vegetarian group.<ref name=R/>
From the 1930-40s Rohits were active in changing their caste name from Khlapa to Rohit, like others such as Dheds to [[Mahyavanshi]]s, Garua to Guru, and [[Bhangi]] to Rishi. Only Mahyavanshis were successful in getting official recognition from the Government of India to get a [[Kshatriya]] status officially. Although Rohit still maintain themselves to be a [[Rajput]], the claim has not been officially accepted by Government of India and they are still considered a sub-caste of [[Chamar]]s.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=GRR5aUwQUVsC&pg=PA92&dq=Rohit++mahyavanshi&hl=en&ei=NOSiTZ7WM8OHrAfyqJ2FAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Rohit%20%20mahyavanshi&f=false] The Mahyavanshi: the success story of a scheduled caste By Y. A. Parmar (Page 91-92)</ref>
==Surname==
The Rohit community has number of ''ataks'' ([[surnames]]) apart from '''Rohit''' generally used by them.<ref name=R>[https://books.google.com/books?id=d8yFaNRcYcsC&pg=PA163&lpg=PA163&dq=rohit+surname&source=bl&ots=krgkqV5Flx&sig=kjfq465y97jQApHrtQZIlZCAruA&hl=en&ei=DkigTf_ZI4HorQexl-X2Ag&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CE8Q6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=rohit%20surname&f=false Bhambhi / Rohit] Gujarat, Part 1 By Kumar Suresh Singh, Rajendra Behari Lal, Anthropological Survey of India. Page 163-165</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
==See also== *[[Rohit]] - a [[Hindu]] name.

{{Infobox Bishopric |border = catholic |font_color = black |bishopric = [[Roman Catholic Diocese of San Jose in California|San José in California]] |coatofarms = |image = |incumbent = [[Patrick Joseph McGrath]]
Installed: 27 November 1999 |province = [[List of Roman Catholic dioceses (structured view)|Ecclesiastical Province of San Francisco]] |diocese = [[Roman Catholic Diocese of San Jose in California|Dioecesis Sancti Josephi in California]] |cathedral = [[Cathedral Basilica of St. Joseph (San Jose)]] |first_bishop = [[Pierre DuMaine]] |date = 1981 |website = [http://www.dsj.org/about-us/bishops/ Bishop of San Jose] }} The '''[[Bishop (Catholic Church)|Roman Catholic Bishop]] of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of San Jose in California|San Jose in California]]''' is the [[Diocesan bishop|head]] of the Roman Catholic Diocese of San Jose in California, being the [[Minister (Catholic Church)|ordinary minister]] of the diocese. As such, he is a member of the [[College of Bishops]], and is responsible for teaching, governing, and [[Bishop (Catholic Church)#Duties|sanctifying]] the faithful of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of San Jose in California]]. In this capacity, he shares or delegates duties with the priests and deacons who serve in the diocese. The sacramental duties and jurisdiction of his ministry is assisted by auxiliary bishops and vicars general. __TOC__ ==List of Bishops== {| class="wikitable" ! !! Name !! Photo !! Start !! End !! Primary Background |- | 1 || [[Pierre DuMaine|Roland Pierre DuMaine]] || || January 27, 1981 || November 27, 1999 || First bishop of the Diocese of San José |- | 2 || [[Patrick Joseph McGrath]] || || November 27, 1999 || Incumbent || Previously served as coadjutor bishop |} ===List of Auxiliary Bishops=== {| class="wikitable" ! !! Name !! Photo !! Start !! End !! Primary Background |- | 1 || [[Thomas A. Daly]] || || May 25, 2011 || May 20, 2015 || First auxiliary bishop of the Diocese of San José |} ==See also== {{Col-begin}} {{Col-2}} * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of San Jose in California]] * [[Diocesan bishop]] * [[Bishop (Catholic Church)]] * [[Auxiliary bishop]] * [[Vicar general]] * [[Holy Orders]] * [[Catholic Church hierarchy]] * [[Minister (Catholic Church)]] {{Col-2}} {{Portal|Christianity|Catholicism}} {{Col-end}} ==External links== * [http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/02581b.htm Information on Bishops at the Catholic Encyclopedia] * [http://www.dsj.org/about-us/bishops Bishops page at the Diocese of San Jose website] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Roman Catholic Diocese of San Jose in California}} [[Category:Roman Catholic bishops of San Jose in California| ]] [[Category:Roman Catholic Diocese of San Jose in California|*]] [[Category:Religious leadership roles]] [[Category:Ecclesiastical titles]] {{US-RC-bishop-stub}}
